title: What is the best interior design software to use for professionals? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Software used in the industry and with their respective functions: Autodesk AutocadFor 2D Plans, drawings, details and sectionsFor 3D planning , but it tend to be on the hard side of 3D workAutodesk Revit:it is used in offices with the BIM workflow.Also used for 2d and 3d drawingsOpens up huge possibilities in managing the whole process of the project , from design to construction all the way to the project management after constructionHarder to learn and if you don't need to use the extra features then CAD is the best optionAdobe creative Suite-Photoshop:Used for rendering plans, creating simple mood images, or to do some post work for renderingsSketchup:Really easy to learn and has a huge library of free 3d models that can be downloaded and used in your projectReally easy to see your project in 3d and test out different layouts and ideasThe more time and energy you invest in it , the more you can produce . It has a lot of Plugins to make professional renders, complex 3d models , parametric architecture, real time walk-through and animationsAutodesk Maya or 3dsmaxUsed for more sophisticated renders and animationsVray, redshift, Renderman and so , all are render extensions for better renderings3Ds max is the best for architecture work since it has some really good plugins for these tasks , but it is really expensiveRhino 3D & GrassHoperif you are interested in Parametric design and complex data oriented designsLumionfor easy realtime renders and animations - fairly good quality for beginners and really good once you dive deeperMicrosoft Office:this might seems out of context, but the basic knowledge here is a mustPowerpoint is the easiest way to layout a presentationExcel for simple site management and team scheduleProjects for full on project managementWord for basic letters, invitations, tendering ..It is important to understand that it is rare to find someone that knows all of these and be a good designer at the same time, these are software used in all the office and spread out on a team of 3 or more. So know your passion and what you enjoy doing and focus on the software that help you do that Hope that i did not forget something

Here in my networking, it depends on which firm/consultant you will apply to. They usually have different requirements, and sometimes there is also some consultant that have no restrictions. But if you’re a freelancer or self-employed that can freely choose the software you’ll be going to use, mostly the essential software that is used and needed are: AutoCAD for 2D layout, SketchUp for 3D modeling, and V-ray for 3D rendering. Actually, you can freely choose and use whatever software you enjoy and good at while working on the project. Because the most important (mostly for the clients) is the final result. And that doesn't always depend on the software you are using. As long as you enjoy using your favorite software, then use it! I personally use AutoCAD for 2D layout, SketchUp for 3D modeling, and 3ds Max Corona Render for 3D rendering. But the first time I learn to make 2D layout, I used ArchiCAD because it’s easier but it’s quite laggy compared to AutoCAD. But the more you can use multiple software, the better. And make sure you have your own favorite software to be mastered at. Or mastered them all.. but we always have that ‘favorite’ one, right? Thank you Aisha for the question, good luck to you!
